results.content: Amazing course with detailed instructions and examples.  Walks through eclipse, tomcat, .jsp, servlets, and some HTML.  Warning through - you need background knowledge in Java & HTML to grasp all the concepts.  If you have that-- then this course is for you! Get answer to questions you might have spent days looking up online like how to include JAR files, how to use the MVC methodology correctly, and how to work with databases.  All in all John does a great job keeping things at the right level for the suggested audience while not getting bogged down.  -- Just follow along and you will emerge with Java Web Application knowledge in your kit bag!

results.content:
I am not exaggerating by this fact:
Two years ago back in September 2014 I decided I would switch careers, and I would go from being a Windows System Administrator, to a more lucrative Java Programming career. I used John's Java for beginners course which helped me GREATLY. 
I succesfully switched careers back in May 2015, and today, September 2016, after watching these JSP and Servlet tutorial, I just received a promotion from Programmer jr. to Programmer.

The content is great, but John encourages you to really go ahead and try to engage your mind into creating scenarios and trying to fix them, I believe John is a talented programmer and didn't need no one to grab his hand and walk him through all the complicated stuff like we non-talented people do need others to walk us through, however, if you really understand his teaching techniques and phylosophy (understanding that he is not the type of guy who puts assignments, exams and homework), and you really go ahead and engage your mind with the topics as he suggests, be creative, challenge your knowledge doing different stuff and try to apply the things you learn into stuff that you can come up with, experiment, move the code, try different things, I can promise you, you will learn greatly from this!

results.content:
The course is decent - I definitely have an understanding of what servlets and jsp's do now, and I had zero idea before.  What I'm lacking though is the 'why' behind all of it.  There's no explanation of the way the technology operates behind the curtain, and there's no explanation of why we should use a servlet as opposed to a jsp.  The course is very heavy on the 'how' aspect, which works to get you up and running, but it really doesn't give me a firm understanding of why I'm actually doing things, I'm mainly just copying what Steve has put on the screen.  When trying to recreate the simple things shown here in other projects to reinforce what I've learned, I often have to reference the course content again because I didn't have any background information on what I was doing, so I didn't have a reference in my head as to what I needed to do.

It's not a bad course, but it's definitely lacking on a lot of the detail I've come to expect from other online courses.

Thank you for this amazing course looking forward spring

results.content:
Before finishing the course:

This course is, by John's own admission, mostly from 2012. It is now early 2020. I'm also throwing caution to the wind(ows) and trying to complete this tutorial using Ubuntu 19.04, Java 11, Tomcat 8.5 Eclipse 2020-03. Even so, everything is working fine and, slowly but surely, the mysteries of bare-bones Java web development are being uncovered in great style by the teacher. Great stuff!

After finishing the course:

The 5 stars remain! The only compatibility problem I ran into was during the FileUploader video. John was using Tomcat 7.0, I stuck with Tomcat 8.5. When getting the file items from the request:

List<FileItem> items = upload.parseRequest(ctx);

one must, with Tomcat 8.5 at least, pass in a 'RequestContext' object. You can get this from the servlet request with:

org.apache.tomcat.util.http.fileupload.RequestContext ctx = new ServletRequestContext(request);

All in all, the Java Servlets + JSPs course remains, 8 years later, a good way to learn Java web programming from the ground up. Having been stuck in a world of JS and Python for the past few years, John's playful approach to teaching is the exact thing I needed to ease me back into the world of proper OOP and static typing.

I'm also throwing caution to the wind(ows) and trying to complete this tutorial using Ubuntu 19.04, Java 11, Tomcat 8.5 Eclipse 2020-03. Even so, everything is working fine and, slowly but surely, the mysteries of bare-bones Java web development are being uncovered in great style by the teacher. Great stuff!

After finishing the course:

The 5 stars remain! The only compatibility problem I ran into was during the FileUploader video. John was using Tomcat 7.0, I stuck with Tomcat 8.5. When getting the file items from the request:

List items = upload.parseRequest(ctx);

one must, with Tomcat 8.5 at least, pass in a 'RequestContext' object. You can get this from the servlet request with:

org.apache.tomcat.util.http.fileupload.RequestContext ctx = new ServletRequestContext(request);

All in all, the Java Servlets + JSPs course remains, 8 years later, a good way to learn Java web programming from the ground up. Having been stuck in a world of JS and Python for the past few years, John's playful approach to teaching is the exact thing I needed to ease me back into the world of proper OOP and static typing.

results.content:
I took this course to refresh my memory on Servlets and jsps. I must say that it accomplished in this aspect and that newcomers will have a lot to learn here.

Pros:
* Click by click tutorials so you cannot miss anything. You can learn a lot, how JEE is integrated with Eclipse
* Forces you to type code along with the author.
* Most examples are written from scratch.
* First few chapters have good examples
* Picture Squirrel is a very good practical example.

Cons:
* Course needs to be updated to the new technologies, fix code errors that appeared with upgrade to new java and tomcat. Database examples will benefit from try-with-resource statements
* I am not sure if author has created these tutorials on the fly during some live broadcast, but he really needs to prepare before recording these courses. During some videos, he simply decides to switch design approaches that he took early on, thus making code obsolete that he wrote moments ago. I am all for intentional mistakes to prove some point, but design choices must be defined at the beginning and should not be deviated from.
* Chapter 4 should provide more examples about given concepts. Some in-depth information about servlet, jsp and tomcat lifecycle would be helpful for course completeness.
* Account example in database chapter could have been much better. Author decided to deviate from its well establish method of showing you everything from scratch and skip servlet related parts to show only database related parts. True, nothing here is something that we haven't already seen, but, for the sake of course completeness, should be there. At least, author should provide starting example of code on which he will add things that he presented.
* There are no examples nor even mentions of Servlet listeners and filters!! 10 hour course should have at least mentioned them as they are commonly used and they are part of servlet specification.
